title: Who will win the 2018 World Series?
possible_answers: A team from the American League
A team from the National League
correct_answer: A team from the American League
preds: Post Mortem: Interestingly, my Brier score is almost identical to the Median. Thus, I didn't add any value to the crowd. My approach was to average between 538 and bettings odds. The betting odds were closer to the eventual truth than 538 and thus I was my Brier is better than somebody who followed 538. Still, that wasn't enough to beat the GJO median. This is in contrast to the FIFA question where following 538 actually led to better-than-median scores. Perhaps this question was an outlier because of the small number of forecasters. Or perhaps one should avoid sports questions if it is hard to consistently beat the median on those due to perhaps the ready availability of great sources like 538.

I have sacrificed a goat, a pig, and a chicken. All the entrails point to the American League. But my tea leaves say National league so I'm going to do a weighted average.

Even without the Philadelphia Athletics, the Washington Senators, and the St. Louis Browns--or maybe especially without them--it looks good for the AL this year.  Since I don't approve of expansion teams and the Dodgers belong in Brooklyn, and although there is a special place in hell for whoever thought up the designated-hitter and no-pitch IP rules, I look forward to a Series in which the Red Sox sweep LA.  This will almost certainly not happen, but at my advanced age one learns to bear up under disappointments.

AL has advantage in WS historically, and in interleague play. This year is an exception with NL winning interleague, but historically has belonged to AL. Will adjust with postseason outcomes. https://www.mlb.com/news/national-league-clinches-interleague-record/c-295235664

Boston and Houston (both American League) are the two best teams in baseball and one of them is highly likely to represent the American League in the World Series.  Both have favorable head-to-head records against the likely NLCS winner.

https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2018-mlb-predictions/?ex_cid=rrpromo has the leading AL teams Astros (22%) and  Red Sox (27%) well ahead of the NL teams Dodgers (9%) and Cubs (8%). That suggests a 75-25 probability. On the other hand, despite the AL having a larger number of seemingly stronger teams, in the last six years the winner has come thrice from each league, which suggests 50-50 would be more prudent. I'm going to stay in the middle for now.

Interesting q. Haven't even checked the teams. So just doing a coward's bet of 50-50 but weighting 0.1 to AmLg just based on crowd/books saying they're favs.  Astroball (2018) 235 page book about a journo claiming Houston Astros would win the WS in 3 years time.   Can Astros go back to back?  ******
https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/37822619-astroball
When Sports Illustrated declared on the cover of a June 2014 issue that the Houston Astros would win the World Series in 2017, people thought Ben Reiter, the article's author, was crazy. The Astros were the worst baseball team in half a century, but they were more than just bad. They were an embarrassment, a club that didn't even appear to be trying to win. The cover story, combined with the specificity of Reiter's claim, met instant and nearly universal derision. But three years later, the critics were proved improbably, astonishingly wrong. How had Reiter predicted it so accurately? And, more important, how had the Astros pulled off the impossible? Astroball is the inside story of how a gang of outsiders went beyond the stats to find a new way to win--and not just in baseball. When new Astros general manager Jeff Luhnow and his top analyst, the former rocket scientist Sig Mejdal, arrived in Houston in 2011, they had already spent more than half a decade trying to understand how human instinct and expertise could be blended with hard numbers such as on-base percentage and strikeout rate to guide their decision-making. In Houston, they had free rein to remake the club. No longer would scouts, with all their subjective, hard-to-quantify opinions, be forced into opposition with the stats guys. Instead, Luhnow and Sig wanted to correct for the biases inherent in human observation, and then roll their scouts' critical thoughts into their process. The numbers had value--but so did the gut. The strategy paid off brilliantly, and surprisingly quickly. It pointed the Astros toward key draft picks like Carlos Correa and Alex Bregman; offered a path for developing George Springer, Jos� Altuve, and Dallas Keuchel; and showed them how veterans like Carlos Beltr�n and Justin Verlander represented the last piece in the puzzle of fielding a championship team. Sitting at the nexus of sports, business, and innovation--and written with years of access to the team's stars and executives--Astroball is the story of the next wave of thinking in baseball and beyond, at once a remarkable underdog story and a fascinating look at the cutting edge of evaluating and optimizing human potential.  ****** Isn't baseball America's sport? I'm forecasting on this question because I've discovered how much more fun and interesting sports are when one has something on the line on the outcome, and that I always learn something when I participate in questions like this.   I just learned, for example, how much stronger the American League is thought to be. My forecasting strategy is one that was perfected by the amazing Khalid; I'm relying on experts, betting pools, etc.  My goals are to have fun, learn something, and not lose a ton of points.
